NEWS BITES

U.K. Property Investors Worry Foreign Buyers Turned Away by Brexit Over 50% of U.K. property investors worry that transactions with foreign buyers will continue to drop, which would further weaken the market, according to a survey by Butterfield Mortgages. Over 80% of these investors also believe that foreign buyers are crucial in order to maintain competition in the property market. City A.M.

Home Sales in Montreal Jump 14% in September Montreal’s residential sales soared 14% year-over-year in September, to a record of 3,659 transactions for the month, according to the Quebec Professional Association of Real Estate Brokers. Median home sale prices increased 6% to C$354,990 (US$266,988) and median condo prices rose by 10% to C$290,000. BNN Bloomberg

Wheelock Properties Suffers Low Sales After Weekend of Hong Kong Protests Wheelock Properties’ new batch of residential units in Tseung Kwan O only managed to sell 20 out of 101 residential units in their new Grand Marini project in Lohas Park after another weekend of protests in Hong Kong. The properties that did sell were primarily one- and two-bedroom units for HK$7 million (US$892,340) and HK$8 million, said Sammy Po, the chief executive of Midland Realty’s residential division. South China Morning Post

Dubai’s Mortgage Defaults Are Not Expected to Be as High as in Past Despite the challenges facing Dubai’s real estate market, mortgage defaults are predicted to not be as high as during past global financial crises, according to Capital Economics. The majority of the boom of property prices in 2012-14 was not paid for in credit but in cash, which would prevent a wave of mortgage defaults as experienced in 2009-10. Khaleej Times

India’s Developers Taken to Court Over Stalled Projects and Unmet Promises Non-Resident Indian buyers have stopped waiting for India’s developers to finish projects and are now taking the developers to the Supreme Court. They have also begun negotiating with other builders to finish projects or are even choosing to finish the work themselves due to the new Real Estate Regulation and Development Act that passed in 2016.
